message: What's the best way to store a user's private data in a way that is actually retrievable (ie, not SHA1 + salt). For example: API keys to other services.
Yeah, I was inspired to actually look through the documentation and discovered a bunch of great stuff I hadn't knows about!
yes, it seems to be actively maintained but stable (last commit ~last november) and I'm sure the google security team knows crypto much better than I do
stop it. you're distracting me from my work damnit!
keyczar is nice in that it takes care of a lot of stuff that can make doing crytpo well hard (e.g. easy key rotation)
Excellent, I didn't expect there to be such a ready-made solution already out there. I don't know why I underestimated the community so!
Django command extensions offers an "encrypted field" which uses google's Keyczar (http://code.google.com/p/keyczar/) to handle the encryption
Ah, very cool! Would you trust important API keys to it? Important as in, misuse of them could cost you money and/or be destructive of your important data?
the DB field stuff I wrote and it's a fairly straightforward use of keyczar so it should be relatively safe, that being said that specifically hasn't had too much explicit review
Well I've (obviously) got an application in mind, so I'll be checking it out. But as you said, Google certainly knows crypto better...
wow. I didn't know that was in command extensions. Thanks @SeanOC
That is specifically for passwords but the concepts can be reused

Playfire have released something around this
Isn't bcrypt one-way?
@treo I don't think so, isn't it one of the algorithms used for harddrive encryption?
@gthank that probably is the better idea, I have had some fun in implementing rsa in clojure, but I wouldn't want to actually use my own implementation :)

@treo As typically used, yes. Technically, bcrypt is built on a key-derivation algorithm (originally used by blowfish), so you could probably take the output from bcrypt and use it as the secret key for an encryption algorithm.
@treo I wouldn't use it that way, though. I try to avoid using crypto primitives like that if I can get a library to put them together for me.
